content.description:
The Abott Pass Hut is located on the boundary between Yoho National Park and Banff National Park.  This climb is listed in Yoho National Park since that is the most sensible and common approach.  The hut is managed by the Alpine Club of Canada.  It is a great base camp if you are attempting climb Mount Victoria or Mount Lefroy.  Many people hike to the hut to stay for the night just for the experience.  There is some red tape involved and the hike there isn't easy. 
  
 The hut was built in 1922 and at 9,598 feet it is the second highest permanent structures in Canada.  The hut is a National Historic Site of Canada.  The hut can sleep 24 people on foam mattresses upstairs.  The kitchen has propane stoves for cooking.  There is a good assortment of pots, pans, dishes, mugs, and cutlery.  There is a wood stove with provide wood for heating.  There is a real nice outhouse. 
  
 The hut can be reserved though the Alpine Club of Canada (ACC)  alpineclubofcanada.ca/huts/….  While reserving the hut with the ACC you can also purchase a backcountry permit and bus passes to Lake OHara.  If you dont have a bus pass its about an eight mile hike along a dirt road to Lake OHara.  American Alpine Club (AAC) members can purchase a Canadian Hut Upgrade from the AAC and save a little bit of money on the hut. 
  
 From Lake OHara it will take four to five hours for an in shape person to reach the hut.  During the hike youll gain about 3,000 feet.  The hike is pleasant until Lake Oesa.  After Lake Oesa is when youll start working your way up a scree slope.  The route is well marked in this area with blue rectangles painted on rocks.  Youll go through a narrow scree gully then across to rock ledges.  Past the rock ledges there is a trail that will take you to the base of the main large scree slope that will take you up to the pass.  In the main scree slope youll gain 1,150 feet of elevation.  Plan to spend some quality time in the scree slope that one climber charmingly called a real meat grinder.  There isnt a route so just keep working your way up the scree slope.  I only caught a few glimpses of the hut while on the scree slope.  The hut is on climbers left.   Helmets are STRONGLY recommended.  Depending on conditions an ice axe and crampons may be required.  Trekking poles can make the scree slope a little easier. 
  
 The weather can change quickly.  It can snow anytime of the year.  Be sure to keep an eye on the weather and go prepared.  This is in an alpine environment and it should be considered a serious undertaking.

Helmets are a real good idea for the scree slope.  Depending on conditions an ice axe and crampons may be required.

climbs.name: Mt Victoria South Peak (main peak) from Lake O'Hara via Huber W Face
climbs.fa: As Climbed by R Hall, M-J Cross, S. Latham, & T. Russler 1978 - FA J.P.Forde, M. Goddard, A.M.Gordon, Mrs A.H.MacCarthy Aug 1909

content.description:
From Lake O'Hara, take hiking path and divert up to the saddle below W face of Mt Huber. (see photo for approx. line; there is an established hiking trail that passes very close to the saddle/col)   Gain and cross the W-Face ("Photo 1') , gaining altitude slowly on ledges and steps (some lose debris on ledges; class 3/4) headed for the West Ridge.  Swing around the W ridge's "corner" and onto the glacier to the north (It was a hanging glacier below where we accessed it in 1978.  GoogleEarth seems to still show this glacier north of Huber. Caution: I believe that GoogleEarth incorrectly labels Mt Huber as "Wiwaxy Peaks" ). I know we initially were still too low on the face to easily gain the glacier, but got a great view of the icefall ("Photo #4").  I don't remember any difficulties climbing up the W Ridge to get to the correct level.

Up this glacier to the open-area "basin" between Huber and Victoria.  Climb whichever gully looks easiest (snow/ice/rock, not necessarily in that order!)  to gain the main (N-S) ridge of Victoria.

Turn left (north ?) and follow the knife-edge-at-times ridge (photo) to the summit of Mt Victoria.

Descend the route.

Ascent is 6000+ vertical feet.

History 

FA by a party (listed above) in Aug 1909 who seemed to have climbed on rock up the final wall (west face of Victoria). Listed in Putnam-Boles Guide to Rocky Mts Canada 1973 as SW Arete of Victoria, route#3 pg 192.  The West ridge ("arete")  of Huber was first climbed by the Stone-Schaufelberger party in 1913 to reach the summit of Huber.

We had attempted Victoria from the Abbot Pass Hut several days before but were unsuccessful due to a combination of slowness on the "lose-slate-on-a-steep-roof" conditions that none of us had experience with, and treating it as a rock climb and leaving the crampons behind. That being said, I feel the direct ascent from Lake O'Hara as described is a better route.  Since one returns the same way, a planned bivi at the col or on the W Face would shorten the day a bit.  You'd want to scout the condition(s) of the Victoria gully(s), and this could probably(?) be done from somewhere on Mt Odaray.

We descended from this "12,000 ft day" (6,000 up, 6,000 down) - one of the best days I have ever had in 50+ years of climbing mountains - to be told there was an emergency phone call for one of our party.  The call-back proved most sad.  Ed Nester, a good friend of every one of our party had died attempting the first ascent of the NorthEast Ridge of Mt. Austerity in the Adamant Range of the Selkirks.  A refrigerator-sized block being used as a rappel anchor had broken off, sending him down several hundred feet into the bergshrund. His partner, Julius Bede, was left on the ridge without rope.  He was rescued three days later by helicopter. Fortunately, there had been another party at the hut and they were able to send someone out to summon the rescue and the RCMP. (This was pre-sat-&-cell phones, and even a radio was rare. )

see photo
Small Alpine" Rack, today I'd take 0.5 through #2 Camalots, long slings and cord to rap off boulders, maybe some "disposable" nuts - Much class 3 "no fall" climbing on W face Huber and along Victoria's ridge. We belayed in the gully, Class 2/3 ice and snow-on-ice.

climbs.name: North West Ridge (aka NW Arete) Mt Schaffer

content.description:
This easy ridge is stunningly viewed from nearly anywhere in the Lake O'Hara basin and provides a easy day scramble plus spectacular scenics of the surrounding mountains: Hungabee, Wiwaxy, Huber, Victoria and Odaray.  I hesitate to give it 4 stars only because I did it so long ago and forget the actual rock quality, which I recollect was quite good. 

From Elizabeth Parker Hut head SouthWest towards Schaffer Lake, swinging around the bottom of the obvious North (NorthWest) Ridge.  Cut back left and gain the ridge which is followed to the top of Mt Schaffer.  Mostly class 2-3 scrambling, some may wish a rope for very short sections.

Descent - For an easier descent take the SouthWest ridge (class 2) down, cutting off the ridge whenever the opportunity to descend towards Schaffer Lake looks best. (we found easy snow on the north-facing right-hand face.

From the Summit of Schaffer, a long ridge runs SouthEast towards, and to, Mt Biddle.

West and south of the Elizabeth Parker Hut.
A short rope and a very small rack may be useful for the occasional step.  larger stuff (1 to 3 inches) more useful if you need it

climbs.name: Odaray via East Face & SE Arete
climbs.fa: jj McArthur  1887;  E Face as climbed by R Hall, MJ Cross, T Russler, T Schlegel, S Latham July 1978

content.description:
Odaray is 10,365 ft and northwest of the Elizabeth Parker hut.

We diverted from the normal SE Arete (SE Ridge) by climbing into the bowl [photo] of the East Face.  In 1978 we encountered very pleasant Class 2 / 3- glacial ice [photo] which we took to the ridgeline. Climbers today should check the condition of the rock between glacier and ridgeline.  

Once rejoined with the 1887 route we continued easily on snow [photo]  and mostly just hiking along on the rock.

The 1973 guidebook* speaks of encountering "two short rock faces" along the ridge.  The first is avoided by "a short traverse to the south".  We reached a highpoint that overlooked a wall that did not look to inviting:  ...very broken, quite surprisingly steep, and generally pretty ugly looking [photo] , especially to us "granite" climbers.  Whether this was face #1 (if it was there seemed to be nothing "short" about any traverse around it) or whether it was #2 not sure.  We think it was #2 because the guidebook said #2 is also "broken by chimneys [and] must be ascended."  ​​​​

We had yet to learn that in the Rockies you really have to be "up close and personal" with the fractured limestone to determine how hard it is.

Nevertheless, to increase our chances of "climbing another day" we had a nice lunch and turned back.

* Italic quotes from Climber's Guide to the Canadian Rockies, 1973, Putnam and Boles 


See photos - take the path north from Elizabeth Parker hut headed towards McArthur Pass and cut left to the mountain.
We took ropes and 2-3 ice screws per "ice leader"; but today most would solo the easy glacial ice.

climbs.name: SE Arete Mt Victoria from Abbot Pass
climbs.fa: J N Collie, C E Fay,  A Michael,  P Sarbach (guide)  Aug 1897

content.description:
I believe this is considered the "Standard" route to climb Mt Victoria.

This is the route from the Abbot Pass hut, of course the hard men of the 1890's climbed the whole route in one day from Lake Louise (taking only 8 hrs for the ascent, and probably returning to Chateau Lake Louise for afternoon tea at 4 ), including going through the "Death Trap" between Mts Victoria and Lefroy on their way to Abbot Pass.  Today most everyone will go to the Abbot Pass Hut via Lake O'Hara and then climb the route from the hut.

We were unsuccessful on our 1978 attempt by this route for a couple of reasons:
1) Except for one of us, no one had ever experienced climbing on what can be likened to "dinner plates of shale lying on top of a steep roof".
2) Because of #1 we roped up for a few rope lengths, thus slowing us.
3) We looked at the route and said "Rock and snow"...leaving crampons behind to save weight, BIG mistake!  
4) We underestimated the length of the ridge once we reached it.

From the Abbot Pass hut climb what amounts to the south face of Victoria, climbing over class 3 broken ground [photo 01] , shale-on-rooftop [photo 02], snow and ice, generally heading to the NW (up-and-leftish).  Cairns will be seen.

Upon reaching the SE Arete proper [photo 03] (essentially the long South-to-North summit ridge [photo04] of Mt Victoria) follow this to the summit.

Descend the route.

Behind the Abbot Pass Hut
A rope will probably be wanted by all on the final snow ridge for simul-climbing along the ridge (see photo of ridge posted to the climb "Mt Victoria via Huber's West Face") and may be wanted by some on the rock steps.
Parks Canada limits access to the Lake O'Hara area.  This prevents too many people from visiting.
